A law of composition on a set $M$ is commutative if $ab = ba$ for all elements $a, b \in M$.
Let $G$ be a group and $H$ a subgroup of $G$. A right coset of $H$ in $G$ is a subset of $G$ of the form $Ha = \{ha; h \in H\}$, where $a \in G$.

The degree of a polynomial f=
sum a_i X^i in R[X], denoted by deg f, is defined as the maximum i such that a_i 
eq 0. The degree is assigned -
infty for the zero polynomial.
For an element $a \in R$, the principal ideal generated by $a$ is $R a:=\{r a ; r \in R\}$. It is the smallest ideal in $R$ containing $a$.
Let $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ be a ring homomorphism. The kernel of $\varphi$, denoted $\operatorname{ker} \varphi$, is defined as $\{a \in R ; \varphi(a)=0\}$, which is an ideal in $R$.
Submodules of an A-module M are defined similarly to subspaces in vector spaces, where a submodule N of M is a subset that is closed under the operations of M.
The unique smallest subfield $P$ of a field $K$, given by the intersection of all subfields in $K$, is referred to as the prime (sub)field in $K$.

For a field $K$ of characteristic $p>0$, the map $\sigma: K \longrightarrow K, \quad a \longmapsto a^{p}$, which respects the addition on $K$, defines a homomorphism of fields known as the Frobenius homomorphism of $K$.

A normal field extension is an extension field that is the splitting field of a family of polynomials from the base field. It is a prestage to Galois extensions. An algebraic field extension \\(K \subset L\\) is called normal if it satisfies the equivalent conditions of Theorem 4: (i) Every \\(K\\)-homomorphism \\(L \longrightarrow \bar{L}\\) into an algebraic closure \\(\bar{L}\\) of \\(L\\) restricts to an automorphism of \\(L\\). (ii) \\(L\\) is a splitting field of a family of polynomials in \\(K[X]\\). (iii) Every irreducible polynomial in \\(K[X]\\) that admits a zero in \\(L\\) decomposes over \\(L\\) completely into linear factors.
Let $G \times X \longrightarrow X$ be an action of a group $G$ on a set $X$. The stabilizer or isotropy subgroup of a point $x \in X$ is defined as $G_{x}:=\{g \in G ; g x=x\}$.
A set is a collection of distinct objects considered as an entity.
